meanings.definition: Treat in an indulgent or overprotective way.
meanings.sent1: She was always coddling her younger brother, making sure he had everything he wanted.
meanings.sent2: The mother couldn't help coddling her newborn baby, showering him with love and attention.
meanings.sent3: The wealthy heiress insisted on coddling her pet poodle, even buying it diamond-studded collars.
meanings.sent4: The coach was accused of coddling the star player, allowing him to skip practice sessions.
meanings.sent5: The teacher believed in challenging her students, not coddling them, to help them grow stronger.

meanings.sent1: After a long week, she decided to coddle herself with a relaxing bubble bath and a good book.
meanings.sent2: The grandparents loved to coddle their grandchildren with treats and toys whenever they visited.
meanings.sent3: He coddled his vintage car, polishing it lovingly every weekend to keep it in pristine condition.
meanings.sent4: The wealthy socialite was used to being coddled by her entourage, who fulfilled her every whim.
meanings.sent5: The pampered celebrity was accustomed to being coddled by assistants, who catered to her every need.

meanings.definition: Cook (an egg) in water below boiling point.
meanings.sent1: To make a perfect soft-boiled egg, you need to coddle it gently in simmering water.
meanings.sent2: She preferred to coddle her eggs rather than hard-boil them, enjoying the creamy texture.
meanings.sent3: The chef demonstrated how to coddle an egg to achieve the ideal consistency for the dish.
meanings.sent4: Coddling eggs requires precision and patience to ensure they are cooked just right.
meanings.sent5: The recipe called for coddling the eggs for exactly three minutes to achieve the desired doneness.
